summary: This is a transcript of a September 1, 2021, OIG interview with Federal Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant Roberto Grijalva, conducted as part of the investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein. The interview focuses on procedures and logs related to the movement of Epstein's cellmate, Efrain Reyes, around the time of Epstein's death. This is a transcript of an OIG interview with a correctional officer regarding the events of August 9, 2019, at the MCC, focusing on the transfer of inmate Efrain Reyes and the failure to assign a new cellmate to Jeffrey Epstein after Reyes left. The interview examines the officer's actions, knowledge, and communication regarding inmate movements and counts.

keyFacts: The interview is part of the official DOJ OIG investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein and surrounding circumstances.
The focus of this segment is on prison procedures and logs related to the movement of Epstein's cellmate, Efrain Reyes, who was 'pre-removed' or 'WAB' (with all belongings) on August 9, 2019.
Lieutenant Grijalva clarifies that 'pre-remove' and 'WAB' are essentially the same procedure, indicating an inmate is leaving the building and most likely not returning.
The document reveals prior OIG interviews with Lt. Grijalva on August 19, 2019, and July 14, 2021, indicating a prolonged investigation.
The interview is conducted under oath and follows a formal voluntary interview procedure with specific DOJ OIG warnings and assurances.
Efrain Reyes was transferred out of the MCC SHU on August 9, 2019, and his status was listed as WAB (With All Belongings), indicating he was not returning.
Jeffrey Epstein was not assigned a new cellmate after Reyes left, despite the interviewing officer stating he told Epstein he would get a new 'bunkie.'
The officer being interviewed was the OIC (Officer in Charge) in the SHU on the morning of August 9, 2019, and was responsible for inmate movements and notifications.
A separate incident involving inmate Fernandez occurred in the SHU visiting room on the same day, where he attempted to grab contraband from a visitor.
The interview reveals confusion and lack of clear responsibility for notifying control about inmate movements and updating counts, contributing to procedural failures.
